suggestions: 4. Return or Destruction of Confidential Information. The Disclosing Party may elect at any time to terminate the Receiving Party’s further access to Confidential Information. At the request of the Disclosing Party or at such time as the Receiving Party decides not to pursue the potential Transaction, the Receiving Party will return or destroy all Confidential Information and shall cause its Representatives to do the same. The Receiving Party will certify such destruction in writing signed by an officer of the Receiving Party. Notwithstanding the foregoing and subject to the provisions of this Agreement, the Receiving Party may retain Confidential Information (a) as required to comply with bona fide legal or regulatory compliance obligations provided that such retained information is segregated and securely managed to prevent unauthorized access, and (b) in electronic format on system back-up tapes or other system back-up media according to industry-standard electronic back-up and archival procedures. Confidential Information so retained will remain subject to the terms of this Agreement notwithstanding its termination for so long as such material is retained. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Receiving Party’s personnel may use Confidential Information retained in their unaided memory, provided such use does not result in intentional disclosure or use of Confidential Information.
originalTexts: 1. Confidential Information.  “Confidential Information” is defined, collectively, as all information conveyed to the Receiving Party or its Representatives (as defined below) regarding the Disclosing Party, its affiliates, its subsidiaries or the potential Transaction, in whatever form, whether oral, electronic or written, whether or not marked or otherwise identified as confidential, and including all notes, analyses, compilations, studies, forecasts, projections, records, interpretations, memoranda, reports or other documents, data, writings and records prepared by or on behalf of the Receiving Party or its Representatives which contain, reflect, are based upon, or are otherwise generated from such information, in whole or in part. Confidential Information also includes the following: (i) that the Disclosing Party is considering the potential Transaction, (ii) that discussions or negotiations have taken, are taking or may take place concerning the potential Transaction, (iii) any of the terms, conditions or other facts with respect to the potential Transaction, including, without limitation, the status of the potential Transaction, (iv) the existence and terms of this Agreement and (v) the fact that Confidential Information has been or may be made available to the Receiving Party and its Representatives. Confidential Information shall not include information that (i) is already in the Receiving Party’s or its Representatives’ possession from a source other than the Disclosing Party so long as that information was not disclosed in violation of an obligation of confidentiality to the Disclosing Party, (ii) is or becomes available to the public other than as a result of a disclosure by the Receiving Party or its Representatives, (iii) is or becomes available to the Receiving Party or its Representatives on a non-confidential basis from a source other than the Disclosing Party or its Representatives, provided that the source of such information did not disclose such information in violation of an obligation of confidentiality to the Disclosing Party, or (iv) the Receiving Party can clearly demonstrate was independently developed by the Receiving Party or its Representatives without use of the Confidential Information.
